user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_MD5_update:
```c
void
MHD_MD5_update (struct Md5Ctx *ctx,
                const uint8_t *data,
                size_t length)
{
  unsigned int bytes_have; /**< Number of bytes in the context buffer */

  mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0));

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

  /* Note: (count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE-1))
           equals (count % MD5_BLOCK_SIZE) for this block size. */
  bytes_have = (unsigned int) (ctx->count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - 1));
  ctx->count += length;

  if (0 != bytes_have)
  {
    unsigned int bytes_left = MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have;
    if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process the full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      md5_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
  }

  while (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)
  {   /* Process any full blocks of new data directly,
         without copying to the buffer. */
    md5_transform (ctx->H, data);
    data += MD5_BLOCK_SIZE;
    length -= MD5_BLOCK_SIZE;
  }

  if (0 != length)
  {   /* Copy incomplete block of new data (if any)
         to the buffer. */
    memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have, data, length);
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_MD5_update:
struct Md5Ctx
{
  uint32_t H[MD5_HASH_SIZE_WORDS];         /**< Intermediate hash value / digest at end of calculation */
  uint32_t buffer[MD5_BLOCK_SIZE_WORDS];   /**< MD5 input data buffer */
  uint64_t count;                          /**< number of bytes, mod 2^64 */
}
...
#define MD5_BLOCK_SIZE (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE_BITS/8)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only pointer usages that relate to const-qualification are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. The fragments selected cover all places in this function where pointers are (a) passed to other functions (md5_transform) or (b) produced by casting the context buffer to a byte pointer for memcpy. These are the locations where const qualification of the pointed-to type could be missing or inconsistent (for example, passing a const-qualified pointer to a callee that takes a non-const pointer, or using a non-const buffer where a const pointer might suffice). Other code in the function does not present pointer const-qualification concerns: the function parameter data is already const-qualified; ctx is modified (count and buffer contents), so it cannot be const; scalar operations (count arithmetic, bytes_have calculation, loop control) do not involve pointer constness; and the mhd_assert and control-flow constructs do not affect pointer const qualification. Therefore only the listed call/copy sites need investigation for Rule 8.13.
